Description: Neck of black-figure painted pottery situla, reconstructed from five fragments. Design black on drab ground, with incised lines and purple accessories. A, combat of two nude Egyptians with clubs; between them, a lotus-flower. Purple on face of man, for club, on some petals of flower and bud.
Curator's comments: This is one side of a situla neck (BMC B.106.1 (= A)); the other side (under a different registration number - BMC B.106.5 (= B)) features the representation of a bull. Petrie 1888 p. 62 considered that the men with clubs were intended for Egyptians, and Cook in his comment in CVA agrees, as they seem to be circumcised and their way of fighting does not look Greek.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B106.1)
CVA British Museum 8 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 13, British Museum 8 (Pl. GB 601, 1-2; GB 598, 6) (Group C9)
Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 62 § 59, pl. xxvi, 3; xxix, 2)
Weber 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus anderen ägyptischen Fundorten (TD 249)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.121, p.122, fig.13a-b, p.123)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2014-2015, 13 Nov-13 Feb, Paris, Musee du Louvre, Rhodos: a Gate from and to the Eastern Mediterranean
